text:
We covered Deep Learning in the #GraknLovesTech blog earlier this month, but today we are looking at Machine Learning. Impacting everything from game playing and online advertising to brain/machine interfaces and medical diagnosis, machine learning explores the construction of algorithms that can learn from and make predictions on data. Rather than following strict program guidelines, machine learning systems build a model based on examples and then make predictions and decisions based on data.

So first things first, we often hear people ask what the difference is between Deep Learning and Machine Learning. So we have gathered a few resources that might help answer that question.

NVidia put out a nice blog post for those wanting a clear explanation of the difference between machine learning and deep learning earlier this year:

Speaking of cats and deep learning, Peter Norvig also has a video explaining how they did it at Google. (Editorial Note: Also because our founder is a huge fan, especially since meeting him in the flesh at the AI conference in NYC earlier this year).

Our friends at KDNuggets also published a guide:

Andrew Ng’s “Machine Learning” MOOC on Coursera is one of the most popular of their entire corpus. Professor Ng published an interesting article earlier this year about what Artificial Intelligence can and cannot do right now in 2016.

Increased accessibility of ML to the wider community

What we noticed about Machine Learning this year, is that it is not so much about massive breakthroughs but rather it was about making it more accessible to more developers and non-specialists.

In November 2016, Amazon announced the launch of its new Amazon AI platform, to deliver the machine learning that Amazon has developed in-house to a broader developer community. For now, the service only makes three different tools available, but the plan is to add more over time.

Earlier in the year, a partnership on AI was signed by Amazon, DeepMind, Google, Facebook, IBM and Microsoft, to advance public understanding of AI, support best practices and develop an open platform for discussion and engagement.

We are looking forward to 2017, to see what it generates.
title: Advent at Grakn Labs: Machine Learning –

text:
We will use more and more Deep Learning to help us find more and more patterns in the ever growing data that surrounds us.

I wouldn’t call this intelligence, but more like “effective and easy to use tools” for thinking automation.

What Deep Learning tools should do is enable us to easily find and extract patterns and accelerate our understanding of complex systems (organic and nonorganic).

What some people may not realize is that the tools that simplify our life must be the ones that should make us smarter.

We live in a world with more and more data pushed through our eyes and ears, most of it I call it noise and sometimes fake.

It is harder and harder to find relevant and useful data, as it is covered by this extra unnecessary data.

The same tools that helps us filter the data are used to generate the noise.

So Artificial Intelligence is not actually Deep Learning, but what we could build using the outcome of deep learning.

Software based intelligent agents (programs) that help us navigate the sea of data and find ground that we could build upon, I see it as next step towards Artificial Intelligence.

Let the machines learn from us as we learned from our parents as kids, and not only learn but also evolve.

To evolve we need more then smart pattern matching techniques, we need dynamic and adaptive reasoning and that needs new ways of thinking and also easy ways to transfer knowledge.

Of course we can make robots, specifically Self Driving Cars, learn how to drive on certain roads using Deep Learning, but unless we look at how we (humans) really do it and replicate that behaviour, we will not have a safe method.

We actually filter and simplify data a lot, and now even faster and more then ever.

Our (brain) computing power did not increase much, but our speed to reduce noise did.

Lets figure out ways to reduce noise, using Artificial Intelligence tools, in all aspects of our life, and increase our power to learn faster and better.

To play with and understand all of these I invite you to join us in the Open Source Self Driving Car (OSSDC) Initiative:

Where we use both robotics and intelligent systems to achieve safe autonomy.

Self Driving Car will be the first autonomous robot deployed at global scale with some kind of Artificial Intelligence, as everyone will be affected then everyone should participate and contribute in defining it.

Follow my journey in robotics and self driving cars on Twitter @gtarobotics
title: What happens next in Artificial Intelligence – Marius Slavescu –

text:
Molto presto i computer non verranno più programmati come oggi, dove sviluppatori creano programmi per specifici compiti. Il prossimo passo sarà quello di addestrarli a risolvere problemi specifici.

Per esempio per insegnare ad una rete neurale artificiale a riconoscere un cane basta mostrargli migliaia di immagini di cani. Il processo continua finché il sistema non sarà in grado di individuare un cane in tutti i contesti.

Questi sistemi sono già ampiamente utilizzati in applicazioni che utilizziamo tutti i giorni. Facebook utilizza questi sistemi per riconoscere le storie sulla vostra timeline o per riconoscere immagini da censurare o per riconoscere le facce dei vostri amici. Anche Microsoft utilizza questi sistemi per tradurre in tempo reale i discorsi su Skype in diverse lingue. Lo stesso approccio è utilizzato nelle automobili che si guidano da sole come le Tesla che imparano a guidare giorno per giorno migliorando in base all’esperienza.

Con le machine learning, l’ingegnere o lo sviluppatore non sa esattamente come il computer svolga i propri compiti. Le operazioni della rete neurale sono in gran parte oscure come in una black box. Quando si analizza una machine learning non si vedono righe di codice ma una vastità di calcoli matematici.

Presto non serviranno programmatori come li conosciamo oggi ma ci saranno figure professionali diverse. Tim O’Reilly sostiene che ci sarà bisogno di programmatori ancora per lungo tempo, ma ad un certo punto il numero scenderà in modo sensibile perché si occuperanno delle architetture che sovraintendono le machine learning più che di programmi specifici.
title: Un programmatore su tre verrà sostituito dall’Intelligenza Artificiale
